column1: # Title:    JWST predicted thermal background for observation planning
# Distribution:  unlimited (see STI approval in attached NASA form 1675B.)
# Pedigree: This is the predicted thermal background for JWST for use in planning observations.
# It is comprised of approx 20 blackbody curves
column2: whose temperatures and areas are distilled

column1: # from far more complicated thermal models.
# This file was generated by Rigby's ipython notebook MIRI background levels_v2.ipynb.
# The input was the SL budget rollup from Paul Lightsey
# which rolls up the stray light into predicted radiances at 10
# approx. twenty different parts of JWST.  That rollup summarizes far more complicated
# underlying stray light and CAD models; the version was v5.3b_0R_P5P_SL1C_FCM_LTOs_C.
# Paul's 9/20/2016 rollup was updated from a previous version of 29 Aug 2016
# For each component in the rollup
column2: this notebook calculated the temperature and

column1: # effective area x emissivity of the blackbody that would produce those radiances
# at 10um and 20um.  The notebook then approximated each component as a blackbody
# and calculated the summed emission from all twenty components.
# The area x emissivivity of the primary mirror was artifically nudged up by 20% to
# better match Paul's predictions at 25 micron.
# The resulting thermal curve agres with the thermal performance estimates
# from Paul Lightsey at 10 and 20 micron within 6%
# with Paul's thermal performance estimates at 15 and 25 micron within 11%.
# Update in v1.1: extending to 31.0 micron as requested by STScI.
# Columns: wavelength (micron) and equivalent sky radiance (MJy/SR)
